unnormalised: Diwali, the festival of lights, is just around the corner, and excitement is building up across India. This year, the main day of Diwali falls on 12/11/2023, a Sunday, promising a long weekend for many. Preparations are in full swing, with homes being cleaned and decorated, and markets bustling with shoppers buying sweets, diyas, and gifts. The festival, deeply rooted in Hindu mythology, symbolizes the victory of good over evil and the triumph of light over darkness.

unnormalised: For many families, the festivities will kick off a few days prior, starting with Dhanteras on 10/11/2023. This day is considered auspicious for buying gold, silver, and new utensils, believed to bring prosperity and good fortune. The following day, 11/11/2023, is Choti Diwali, marked by smaller celebrations and the lighting of diyas in the evening. However, the highlight remains the main Diwali day.

unnormalised: On 12th Nov, families will gather for Lakshmi Puja, a prayer ritual dedicated to the goddess of wealth and prosperity. This is usually performed in the evening, around 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM, considered an auspicious time. After the puja, people exchange gifts, share sweets, and light firecrackers to celebrate the occasion. While celebrations are expected to go late into the night, environmental concerns have led to calls for responsible firecracker usage.

unnormalised: Many cities are already planning special events and cultural programs to mark Diwali. In Ayodhya, a grand 'Deepotsav' is scheduled for 11/11/23-12/11/23, with a record number of diyas expected to be lit on the banks of the Saryu River. Similar events are planned in Varanasi, Jaipur, and other major cities, showcasing the rich cultural heritage of India.

unnormalised: For those planning to travel during Diwali, it's advisable to book tickets well in advance, as trains and flights tend to be fully booked during this period. The rush typically starts a week before the festival and continues for several days after, with many people heading back to their hometowns to celebrate with their families. It is expected that most people start travelling at around 18:00 on 10/11/2023.

unnormalised: While Diwali is primarily a Hindu festival, it is celebrated by people of all faiths in India, reflecting the country's diverse and inclusive culture. The festival is a time for family reunions, community gatherings, and spreading joy and goodwill. It marks a period of new beginnings and positive energy, as people look forward to a brighter and more prosperous future. Many businesses are expected to be closed from 12/11/23 to 13/11/23 for the holiday.
